main.docTitle: Merchant Shipping (Seafarers) (Working and Living Conditions) Regulation

section.name: s2
section.heading: Interpretation

subsection.leadIn: In this Regulation—
subsection.def: approved training programme (認可訓練課程) means a training programme for seafarers approved by the Superintendent;
*commencement date (生效日期) means the date on which this Regulation comes into operation; (L.N. 174 of 2018)

competent authority (主管當局), in relation to a ML Convention country, or a country that is a party to the Ships’ Cooks Convention, means the authority with the power to enforce, in the country, the law for implementing the Convention concerned;

complaint procedures (投訴程序), in relation to a ship, means the procedures for dealing with complaints from seafarers working on board the ship regarding alleged breaches of the Part 2 requirements applicable to the ship;

compliance report (合規報告) means a compliance report issued—(a)by the Authority under section 91;(b)by the competent authority of a ML Convention country under section 115; or(c)by a recognized organization; (L.N. 174 of 2018)
Convention-related document (《公約》相關文件) means—(a)a maritime labour certificate;(b)an interim maritime labour certificate;(c)a compliance report; or(d)a declaration of maritime labour compliance;

declaration of maritime labour compliance (海事勞工合規聲明) means a declaration of maritime labour compliance comprising—(a)Part I which is issued by the Authority under section 82(1) or 93(1); and(b)Part II which is issued—(i)by the Authority under section 82(3) or 93(3);(ii)by the competent authority of a ML Convention country under section 115; or(iii)by a recognized organization;

endorsement for intermediate inspection (中期檢查批註) means an endorsement for an intermediate inspection that is made on the maritime labour certificate of a ship—(a)by the Authority under section 74;(b)by the competent authority of a ML Convention country under section 115; or(c)by a recognized organization;
function (職能) includes power and duty;
Government surveyor (政府驗船師) means a person appointed to be a Government surveyor under section 110;

gross tonnage (總噸位), in relation to a ship, means the gross tonnage of the ship determined in accordance with regulation 6 of the Merchant Shipping (Registration) (Tonnage) Regulations (Cap. 415 sub. leg. C);
Hong Kong ship (香港船舶) means a ship registered in Hong Kong under the Merchant Shipping (Registration) Ordinance (Cap. 415);
hours of rest (休息時間) means any period of time outside working hours, but does not include short breaks within working hours;

interim maritime labour certificate (臨時海事勞工證書) means an interim maritime labour certificate issued—(a)by the Authority under section 78;(b)by the competent authority of a ML Convention country under section 115; or(c)by a recognized organization;
intermediate inspection (中期檢查) means an intermediate inspection carried out in respect of a ship under section 73(1);

maritime labour certificate (海事勞工證書) means a maritime labour certificate issued or renewed—(a)by the Authority under section 69, 70 or 72;(b)by the competent authority of a ML Convention country under section 115; or(c)by a recognized organization;
medical care (醫療照顧) includes dental care;

ML Convention (《海事勞工公約》) means the Maritime Labour Convention, 2006, adopted by the International Labour Conference of the International Labour Organization on 23 February 2006, as from time to time revised or amended by any revision or amendment to any provision of the Convention that applies to Hong Kong;
ML Convention country (《海事勞工公約》國) means a country that is a party to the ML Convention, and includes a place to which the Convention applies;
non-Hong Kong ship (非香港船舶) means a ship other than a Hong Kong ship;
official log book (正式航海日誌) means an official log book kept on a Hong Kong ship under section 119 of the Ordinance;
preliminary certificate (初步證書) means a preliminary certificate referred to in section 70(2)(a)(ii);
recognized organization (認可機構) means an organization recognized under section 111;

regulated ship (受管制船舶) means a seagoing ship, whether publicly or privately owned, that is engaged in commercial activities, but does not include—(a)a fishing vessel;(b)a ship of traditional build, including a dhow or a junk; or(c)a warship or naval auxiliary;

seagoing ship (海域航行船舶) means a ship other than one which navigates exclusively in one or more of the following areas—(a)inland waters;(b)waters within, or closely adjacent to, sheltered waters;(c)areas where port regulations apply;

shipowner (船東)—(a)in relation to a Hong Kong ship in respect of which a maritime labour certificate or compliance report is in force, means the person identified as the shipowner of the ship on the certificate or report; or(b)in relation to any other Hong Kong ship—(i)means the person registered as the owner of the ship under the Merchant Shipping (Registration) Ordinance (Cap. 415); or(ii)means a person who has assumed responsibility for the operation of the ship from the owner of the ship and who, on assuming the responsibility, has agreed to take over the obligations imposed on the owner of the ship under the ML Convention;

STCW Code (《培訓規則》) means the Seafarers’ Training, Certification and Watchkeeping Code published by the International Maritime Organization, as from time to time revised or amended by any revision or amendment that applies to Hong Kong;

STCW Convention (《培訓公約》) means the International Convention on Standards of Training, Certification and Watchkeeping for Seafarers, 1978, as from time to time revised or amended by any revision or amendment to any provision of the Convention that applies to Hong Kong;
young seafarer (青年海員) means a seafarer who is under the age of 18.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Regulation, a ship is constructed when—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: its keel is laid; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is at a similar stage of construction.

part.name: P2
part.heading: Requirements Relating to Working and Living Conditions of Seafarers

section.name: s3
section.heading: Application
section.content: This Part applies to a regulated ship that is a Hong Kong ship, wherever it may be.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Working and living conditions of seafarers
section.content: The working and living conditions of seafarers employed to work on board a ship must comply with the requirements specified in Divisions 2 to 17.

division.name: D2
division.heading: Minimum Age and Other Age-related Requirements

section.name: s5
section.heading: Minimum age
section.content: A seafarer who works on board a ship must be at least 17 years of age.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Young seafarers must not work during night period

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2), a young seafarer employed to work on board a ship must have a night rest period that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: lasts at least 9 consecutive hours; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: includes the hours between midnight and 5 a.m.

subsection.leadIn: The seafarer must not work during the period unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the training for the seafarer in accordance with an approved training programme would be impaired; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the specific nature of the duty of the seafarer or of an approved training programme requires the seafarer to work during the period and the work to be carried out—

subparagraph.content: falls within Regulations II/1 and II/3 of the STCW Convention;
forms part of the training for engineer officer under Regulation III/1 of the STCW Convention;
forms part of the training for navigational watch rating under Regulation II/4 of the STCW Convention;
forms part of the training for engine room watch rating under Regulation III/4 of the STCW Convention;
forms part of the training for rating as able seafarer deck under Regulation II/5 of the STCW Convention;
forms part of the training for rating as able seafarer engine under Regulation III/5 of the STCW Convention;
forms part of the training for electro-technical officer under Regulation III/6 of the STCW Convention;
forms part of the training for electro-technical rating under Regulation III/7 of the STCW Convention;
forms part of the training for radio personnel under Regulation IV/2 of the STCW Convention;
forms part of the training for alternative certification under Regulation VII of the STCW Convention.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Young seafarers must not carry out certain types of work

subsection.leadIn: A young seafarer employed to work on board a ship must not carry out any work—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that has to be carried out in a high-pressure atmosphere and that would expose the seafarer to risks of high pressure and decompression;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that involves taking care of or coming into contact with patients on board the ship;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: that would expose the seafarer to electrical voltage of over 1 000 volts;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: that would expose the seafarer to—

subparagraph.content: shocks that could cause back pain to, or damage to the spine of, the seafarer; or
low-frequency vibration; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: that involves the handling of—

subparagraph.content: any substance listed in the Dangerous Goods List of the IMDG Code; or
any noxious liquid listed in Chapter 17 of the IBC Code.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: IBC Code (《國際散裝化學品規則》) means the International Code for the Construction and Equipment of Ships Carrying Dangerous Chemicals in Bulk published by the International Maritime Organization, as from time to time revised or amended by any revision or amendment that applies to Hong Kong;

IMDG Code (《危險貨物守則》) means the International Maritime Dangerous Goods Code published by the International Maritime Organization, as from time to time revised or amended by any revision or amendment that applies to Hong Kong.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Young seafarers must not carry out certain types of work without training etc.

subsection.leadIn: A young seafarer employed to work on board a ship must not carry out any work specified in subsection (2) unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the seafarer has completed a relevant approved training programme; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the seafarer is provided with appropriate supervision and instruction by an officer on board the ship for carrying out the work.

subsection.leadIn: The work is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: lifting, moving or carrying heavy loads or objects;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: work that involves entry into boilers, tanks and cofferdams;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: work that involves exposure to harmful noise and vibration levels;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: operating hoisting and other power machinery or tools, or acting as signallers to operators of the machinery or tools;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: handling mooring or tow lines or anchoring equipment;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: rigging;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: working aloft or on deck in heavy weather;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: nightwatch duties;
servicing electrical equipment;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: work that involves exposure to potentially harmful materials, or harmful physical agents, including dangerous or toxic substances and ionizing radiations;

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: cleaning catering machinery;
handling or taking charge of ship’s boats.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Offences

subsection.content: If section 5 is contravened, the shipowner of the ship concerned commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 2 years.

subsection.leadIn: If section 6, 7 or 8 is contravened, the shipowner and the master of the ship concerned each commits an offence and is liable on conviction—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for the shipowner, to a fine at level 6;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the master, to a fine at level 4.

section.name: s10
section.heading: Seafarer must hold medical fitness certificate
section.content: A seafarer employed to work on board a ship must hold a valid medical fitness certificate.

section.name: s11
section.heading: Qualifications and training

subsection.content: A seafarer must not work in any capacity on board a ship unless the seafarer complies with the requirements in respect of that capacity imposed by the subsidiary legislation made under the Ordinance for implementing the STCW Convention.
A seafarer must not work on board a ship unless the seafarer has completed the training for personal safety in compliance with the STCW Code.

section.name: s12
section.heading: Seafarers must have entered into employment agreements

subsection.content: A seafarer working on board a ship must have entered into a written employment agreement with the employer of the seafarer.

subsection.leadIn: The seafarer must be given—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an opportunity to examine and seek advice on the agreement before entering into it; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: any facilities that are necessary to ensure that the seafarer—

subparagraph.content: has a sufficient understanding of the seafarer’s rights and obligations under the agreement before entering into it; and
freely enters into the agreement.

subsection.content: The seafarer must be given a signed original of the agreement.
If the agreement is not in English, a copy of a standard form of the agreement adopted for seafarers on board the ship in English must be made available to the seafarer.

section.name: s13
section.heading: Requirements for employment agreement
section.content: An employment agreement of a seafarer must comply with Schedule 1.

section.name: s14
section.heading: Employment agreement to be made available for review
section.content: A copy of the employment agreement between a seafarer and the employer of the seafarer must, on request, be made available for review by the competent authority of a ML Convention country.

section.name: s15
section.heading: Record of employment

subsection.content: A seafarer must, before being discharged from the ship on which the seafarer has worked, be given a record of the seafarer’s employment on board the ship that complies with subsection (2).

subsection.leadIn: The record of employment—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must contain sufficient information to facilitate the seafarer to acquire further work, or to satisfy the sea-service requirements for the seafarer’s upgrading or promotion; but

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must not contain any statement as to the wages of the seafarer or quality of the seafarer’s work.

section.name: s16
section.heading: Offences

subsection.content: If section 12(2) is contravened, the employer of the seafarer concerned commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 6 months.
If section 12(3) or (4) is contravened, the employer of the seafarer concerned commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3.
If section 13 is contravened, the employer of the seafarer concerned commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 6 months.
If section 14 or 15(1) is contravened, the employer of the seafarer concerned commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3.
It is a defence for a person charged under subsection (1) or (2) to show that the person had taken all reasonable steps to prevent the commission of the offence.

division.name: D6
division.heading: Use of Recruitment and Placement Services

section.name: s17
section.heading: Recruitment and placement agent in ML Convention country
section.content: If the shipowner of a ship engages an agent operating in a ML Convention country to recruit and place seafarers to work on board the ship, the shipowner must ensure that the agent is permitted to do so under the law of the country.

section.name: s18
section.heading: Recruitment and placement agent in other countries

subsection.content: If the shipowner of a ship engages an agent operating in a country, not being a ML Convention country, to recruit and place seafarers to work on board the ship, the shipowner must, as far as practicable, ensure that the agent complies with all the requirements specified in subsection (2).

subsection.leadIn: The requirements are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the agent must not use any means, mechanism or list to prevent or deter a seafarer from gaining employment for which the seafarer is qualified;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the agent must not require a seafarer to bear, whether directly or indirectly, in part or in whole, any fees or charges for arranging employment for the seafarer;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the agent must maintain an up-to-date register of all seafarers recruited or placed by it;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: the agent must have measures in place to ensure that—

subparagraph.content: a seafarer to be employed is informed of the seafarer’s rights and obligations under the employment agreement to be entered into;
the agreement complies with Schedule 1;
the seafarer has an opportunity to examine and seek advice on the agreement before entering into it; and (L.N. 174 of 2018)
the seafarer receives a copy of the agreement after entering into it; (L.N. 174 of 2018)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the agent must have measures in place to verify that a seafarer recruited or placed by it to take up a position on board the ship is qualified for, and holds the documents necessary for, the position;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the agent must have measures in place to ensure, as far as practicable, that the shipowner has the means to protect a seafarer employed or placed from being stranded in a foreign port;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.leadIn: the agent must—

subparagraph.content: have measures in place, whether by way of insurance or otherwise, to compensate a seafarer employed for any monetary loss that the seafarer may incur as a result of the failure of the agent or the shipowner to meet its obligation to the seafarer; and
ensure that the seafarer is informed of the seafarer’s rights under those measures before entering into the employment agreement. (L.N. 21 of 2024)

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (2)(b), the fees or charges for arranging employment for a seafarer does not include the cost of obtaining—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the seafarer’s medical fitness certificate;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the seafarer’s record of employment; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the seafarer’s passport or other similar personal travel documents, other than a visa required for travelling to a place in the course of employment.

section.name: s19
section.heading: Offences

subsection.content: The shipowner of a ship who contravenes section 17 or 18(1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5.
It is a defence for a person charged under subsection (1) to show that the person had taken all reasonable steps to prevent the commission of the offence.

section.name: s20
section.heading: Minimum hours of rest

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2) and section 21, a seafarer employed to work on board a ship must have at least—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: 10 continuous hours of rest in any 24-hour period; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: 77 hours of rest in any 7-day period.

subsection.leadIn: The hours of rest in a 24-hour period may be divided into 2 periods if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: one of them is at least 6 hours in duration; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the interval between 2 consecutive periods of rest does not exceed 14 hours.

subsection.leadIn: Emergency drills on board the ship must be conducted in a manner—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that minimizes the disruption of any rest period; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that does not induce fatigue to any seafarer on board the ship.

section.name: s21
section.heading: Authority may permit exceptions
section.content: The Authority may, in accordance with Standard A2.3 of the ML Convention and section A-VIII/1 of the STCW Code, permit an exception to the requirements on hours of rest under section 20(1) and (2).

section.name: s22
section.heading: Schedules of service and records of rest

subsection.leadIn: The master of a ship must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: compile a table that complies with subsection (2); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: display the table in a conspicuous position on board the ship, which is accessible to the seafarers on it.

subsection.leadIn: The table must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: contain, in respect of each seafarer on board the ship—

subparagraph.content: a schedule of service at sea and service in port; and
the minimum hours of rest; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: be presented—

subparagraph.content: in the working language of the crew of the ship; and
if the working language is not English, also in English.

subsection.leadIn: The master may require a seafarer to work during the hours of rest shown in the schedule of service for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: ensuring the immediate safety of the ship, or a person or cargo on board the ship; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: giving assistance to any other ship or a person in distress at sea.

subsection.content: If a seafarer has worked pursuant to subsection (3), the seafarer must be provided with a compensatory rest period.

subsection.leadIn: The master must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: maintain a record of daily hours of rest of every seafarer on board the ship that is endorsed by—

subparagraph.content: the master or a person authorized by the master; and
the seafarer; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: provide each seafarer with a copy of the record relating to the seafarer.

section.name: s23
section.heading: Working hours of young seafarers

subsection.leadIn: The following requirements must be complied with in relation to a young seafarer employed to work on board a ship—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the working hours of the seafarer must not exceed—

subparagraph.content: 8 hours in any 24-hour period; and
40 hours in any 7-day period;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: there must be—

subparagraph.content: sufficient time for meals; and
a break of at least 1 hour for the main meal of a day; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: there must be a 15-minute rest period as soon as practicable after every 2 hours of continuous work.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) does not apply if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the seafarer is assigned to watchkeeping duties or working on a rostered shiftwork system in the deck department, engine room department or catering department, and it is impracticable for the requirements to be complied with;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: it is necessary for the seafarer to work for extra working hours to—

subparagraph.content: ensure the immediate safety of the ship, or a person or cargo on board the ship; or
give assistance to any other ship or a person in distress at sea; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the training for the seafarer in accordance with an approved training programme would be impaired.

subsection.leadIn: If any of the requirements specified in subsection (1) is not complied with in relation to a seafarer because of subsection (2), the master of the ship concerned must compile and sign a record containing the following particulars—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the duration of the extra working hours; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the circumstances under which the working hours of the seafarer are exceeded.

section.name: s24
section.heading: Offences

subsection.leadIn: If section 20(1) or (3) or 22(4) is contravened, the shipowner and the master of the ship concerned each commits an offence and is liable on conviction—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for the shipowner, to a fine at level 5;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the master, to a fine at level 3.

subsection.content: The master of a ship who contravenes section 22(1) or (5) or 23(3) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 1.

subsection.leadIn: If section 23(1) is contravened, the shipowner and the master of the ship concerned each commits an offence and is liable on conviction—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for the shipowner, to a fine at level 5;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the master, to a fine at level 3.

subsection.content: It is a defence for a person charged under subsection (1), (2) or (3) to show that the person had taken all reasonable steps to prevent the commission of the offence.

section.name: s25
section.heading: Sufficient number of seafarers to ensure safety of ship etc.

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to the requirements on manning of ships under the Merchant Shipping (Seafarers) (Certification of Officers) Regulation (Cap. 478 sub. leg. J)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: there must be a sufficient number of seafarers on board a ship to ensure that the ship is operated safely and efficiently, with due regard to security; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the ship must be manned by a crew that is adequate, in terms of size and qualifications, to ensure the safety and security of the ship and all the persons on board the ship under all operating conditions.

subsection.content: A ship issued with a Minimum Safe Manning Certificate under the Merchant Shipping (Safety) (Minimum Safe Manning Certificate) Regulation (Cap. 369 sub. leg. AS) is taken to have complied with subsection (1) if the ship is manned in accordance with the Certificate.
If subsection (1) is contravened, the shipowner of the ship concerned commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 2 years.

section.name: s26
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Division—
section.def: special purpose ship (特殊用途船舶) means a ship that complies with the requirements for special purpose ships set out in the Code of Safety for Special Purpose Ships adopted by the International Maritime Organization by Resolution A.534(13), as amended from time to time.

section.name: s27
section.heading: Accommodation and related requirements

subsection.content: Subject to sections 29, 30 and 31, a ship constructed on or after the commencement date must comply with Schedule 2.
A ship constructed before the commencement date must comply with the accommodation and related requirements that apply to it under the Accommodation Regulation.

section.name: s28
section.heading: Regular inspections to be carried out regarding accommodation and related facilities

subsection.content: The master of a ship constructed on or after the commencement date must carry out an inspection of the ship once every week to ensure that the accommodation and related facilities for seafarers are clean and maintained in a good state of repair.
The master may appoint an officer on board the ship to carry out the inspection on behalf of the master.
The master must ensure that the master or the officer appointed is accompanied by another seafarer on board the ship during the inspection.

subsection.leadIn: The master must ensure that, for each inspection, a record that complies with subsection (5)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is entered in the ship’s official log book; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is, on request, made available for review by a port authority.

subsection.leadIn: The record of inspection must contain the following information—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the time and date of the inspection;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the name and rank of each seafarer—

subparagraph.content: who carried out the inspection; or
who was present during the inspection under subsection (3); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the items inspected and details of non-compliance with Schedule 2, if any.

section.name: s29
section.heading: Exemptions for ships of less than 200 gross tonnage

subsection.content: The Authority may, after consulting the Advisory Board, exempt a ship constructed on or after the commencement date that is of less than 200 gross tonnage from any of the requirements specified in subsection (2).

subsection.leadIn: The requirements are those under Standard A3.1 of the ML Convention relating to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: air conditioning;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: washbasins in sleeping rooms;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: laundry facilities;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the floor area of sleeping rooms for seafarers.

subsection.leadIn: The Authority may only grant an exemption under subsection (1) if the Authority considers it reasonable to do so, having regard to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the size of the ship; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the number of persons to be carried on board the ship.

section.name: s30
section.heading: Exemptions for ships of less than 3 000 gross tonnage and special purpose ships

subsection.content: The Authority may, after consulting the Advisory Board, exempt a ship constructed on or after the commencement date that is of less than 3 000 gross tonnage from any of the requirements specified in subsection (2).

subsection.leadIn: The requirements are those under Standard A3.1 of the ML Convention relating to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the provision of individual sleeping room for each seafarer;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the provision of adjoining sitting rooms, day rooms or equivalent additional spaces to the master, chief engineer and chief navigating officer;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the location of mess rooms;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the provision of sanitary facilities within easy access of the navigating bridge and the machinery space or near the engine room control centre;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the provision of separate offices or a common ship’s office for use by the deck department and engine room department.

subsection.content: The Authority may, after consulting the Advisory Board, exempt a ship constructed on or after the commencement date that is a special purpose ship from the requirement relating to the provision of individual sleeping room for each seafarer under Standard A3.1 of the ML Convention.

subsection.leadIn: The Authority may only grant an exemption under subsection (1) or (3) if the Authority considers it reasonable to do so, having regard to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the space available on the ship;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the effect of the exemption on the structure of the ship; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the effect of the exemption on the safety of the persons on board the ship.

section.name: s31
section.heading: Variations in requirements set out in Schedule 2

subsection.content: This section applies to a ship that is constructed on or after the commencement date.

subsection.leadIn: The Authority may allow a reduction in the minimum permitted headroom in the accommodation for seafarers on board a ship required under Standard A3.1 of the ML Convention, if the Authority is satisfied that the reduction—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is reasonable; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: will not result in discomfort to the seafarers.

subsection.content: The Authority may allow the sleeping rooms on a passenger ship or special purpose ship to be located below the load line (but not to be located immediately beneath working alleyways), if satisfactory arrangements are made for the lighting and ventilation of the ship.
The Authority may, for providing single berth sleeping rooms on board a ship that is of less than 3 000 gross tonnage, allow the floor area of such a sleeping room to be less than 4.5 m2.

The Authority may allow a reduction in the number of sanitary facilities required of a ship under Standard A3.1 of the ML Convention, if the ship is a passenger ship normally engaged in voyages of not more than 4 hours’ duration.

section.name: s32
section.heading: Offences

subsection.content: If section 27(1) is contravened, the shipowner and the master of the ship concerned each commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5.
The master of a ship who contravenes section 28(1), (3) or (4) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3.
It is a defence for a person charged under subsection (2) to show that the person had taken all reasonable steps to prevent the commission of the offence.

section.name: s33
section.heading: Requirements for recreational and communications facilities

subsection.content: A ship constructed on or after the commencement date must comply with Schedule 3.
A ship constructed before the commencement date must comply with the requirements for recreational and communications facilities that apply to it under the Accommodation Regulation.

section.name: s34
section.heading: Regular inspections to be carried out regarding recreational and communications facilities

subsection.content: The master of a ship constructed on or after the commencement date must carry out an inspection of the ship once every week to ensure that the recreational and communications facilities for seafarers are clean and maintained in a good state of repair.
The master may appoint an officer on board the ship to carry out the inspection on behalf of the master.
The master must ensure that the master or the officer appointed is accompanied by another seafarer on board the ship during the inspection.

subsection.leadIn: The master must ensure that, for each inspection, a record that complies with subsection (5)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is entered in the ship’s official log book; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is, on request, made available for review by a port authority.

subsection.leadIn: The record of inspection must contain the following information—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the time and date of the inspection;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the name and rank of each seafarer—

subparagraph.content: who carried out the inspection; or
who was present during the inspection under subsection (3); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the items inspected and details of non-compliance with Schedule 3, if any.

section.name: s35
section.heading: Offences

subsection.content: If section 33(1) is contravened, the shipowner and the master of the ship concerned each commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5.
The master of a ship who contravenes section 34(1), (3) or (4) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3.
It is a defence for a person charged under subsection (2) to show that the person had taken all reasonable steps to prevent the commission of the offence.

section.name: s36
section.heading: Sufficient provisions and drinking water to be provided

subsection.content: The shipowner of a ship must ensure that the seafarers working on board the ship are provided with provisions and drinking water in compliance with subsection (2).

subsection.leadIn: The provisions and drinking water must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be suitable in quantity, nutritional value, quality and variety, having regard to the number of seafarers on board the ship, their religious and cultural background, and the duration and nature of the voyage; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be provided free of charge.

section.name: s37
section.heading: Staffing requirements for catering department
section.content: The shipowner of a ship must ensure that the catering department of the ship is staffed in compliance with Schedule 4.

section.name: s38
section.heading: Organization and equipment of catering department
section.leadIn: The master of a ship must ensure that the catering department of the ship is so organized and equipped that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: adequate, balanced, nutritious and varied meals may be prepared; and (L.N. 21 of 2024)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: meals may be served in hygienic conditions.

section.name: s39
section.heading: Regular inspections to be carried out regarding provisions, drinking water, etc.

subsection.leadIn: The master of a ship must ensure that an inspection is carried out once every week in compliance with subsection (2) regarding—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the supply of provisions and drinking water referred to in section 36;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the space and equipment used for storing and handling provisions and drinking water; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the galley and other equipment used for preparing and serving meals.

subsection.leadIn: The inspection must be carried out by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the master or a person authorized by the master; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a seafarer employed in the catering department of the ship.

subsection.leadIn: The master must ensure that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the result of each inspection is entered in the ship’s official log book; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: each entry in the book is signed by all the persons who carried out the inspection.

section.name: s40
section.heading: Offences

subsection.content: The shipowner of a ship who contravenes section 36 or 37 commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5.
The master of a ship who contravenes section 38 commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5.
The master of a ship who contravenes section 39(1) or (3) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3.
It is a defence for a person charged under subsection (1), (2) or (3) to show that the person had taken all reasonable steps to prevent the commission of the offence.

section.name: s41
section.heading: Health and safety of seafarers
section.content: Sections 4 and 6 of the Merchant Shipping (Seafarers) (Health and Safety: General Duties) Regulation (Cap. 478 sub. leg. C) must be complied with in relation to a ship.

section.name: s42
section.heading: Appointment of safety officials and reporting of accidents etc.
section.content: Sections 4, 12 and 12A of the Merchant Shipping (Seafarers) (Safety Officials and Reporting of Accidents, Dangerous Occurrences and Occupational Diseases) Regulation (Cap. 478 sub. leg. R) must be complied with in relation to a ship.

section.name: s43
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Division—
section.def: qualified dentist (合資格牙醫) means—(a)a registered dentist as defined by section 2(1) of the Dentists Registration Ordinance (Cap. 156); or(b)a person who is qualified to practise dentistry in a country that is a party to the STCW Convention;

qualified medical practitioner (合資格醫生) means—(a)a registered medical practitioner as defined by section 2(1) of the Medical Registration Ordinance (Cap. 161); or(b)a person who is qualified to practise medicine in a country that is a party to the STCW Convention.

section.name: s44
section.heading: Qualified medical practitioner to be carried on ship
section.leadIn: A qualified medical practitioner must be carried on board a ship if the ship—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: carries 100 or more persons; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: is engaged in a voyage—

subparagraph.content: that is of more than 3 days’ duration; and
that is wholly or partly outside the river trade limits.

section.name: s45
section.heading: Seafarers to be in charge of medical care on board etc.

subsection.leadIn: If a ship is not required to have a qualified medical practitioner on board the ship under section 44, the shipowner of the ship must ensure that there is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: at least one seafarer on board the ship who—

subparagraph.content: is responsible for providing medical care and administering medicine; and
is a qualified seafarer; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at least one seafarer on board the ship who is competent to provide medical first aid.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1)(a)(ii), a seafarer is a qualified seafarer if the seafarer—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: meets the standard of competence in medical care specified in section A-VI/4, paragraphs 4, 5 and 6 of the STCW Code; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has taken a refresher course on medical care, which had been approved by the Authority or the competent authority of a ML Convention country, within the previous 5 years.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1)(b), a seafarer is competent to provide medical first aid if the seafarer—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: meets the standard of competence in medical first aid specified in section A-VI/4, paragraphs 1, 2 and 3 of the STCW Code; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has taken a refresher course on medical first aid, which had been approved by the Authority or the competent authority of a ML Convention country, within the previous 5 years.

subsection.leadIn: The Authority may approve a refresher course referred to in subsection (2)(b) or (3)(b) if the Authority is satisfied that the course may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: refresh seafarers’ knowledge and skills on medical care or medical first aid; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: provide seafarers with information on new developments in medical care or medical first aid.

section.name: s46
section.heading: Shipowner to ensure medical care

subsection.content: The shipowner of a ship must ensure that a seafarer working on board the ship is provided with medical care that complies with all the requirements specified in subsection (2).

subsection.leadIn: The requirements are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the medical care must be appropriate, having regard to the duties to be carried out by the seafarer and the special requirements related to working on board the ship;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the medical care must be as comparable as possible to that which is generally made available to workers ashore, including prompt access to—

subparagraph.content: the necessary medicines, medical equipment and facilities for diagnosis and treatment; and
medical information and expertise;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: where practicable, the seafarer may visit a qualified medical practitioner or qualified dentist without delay in a port of call;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the medical care must be provided free of charge.

section.name: s46A
section.heading: Shipowner to deliver body or ashes of deceased seafarer
section.leadIn: If a seafarer dies on board a ship or ashore in the course of employment, the shipowner of the ship must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: arrange the body or ashes of the seafarer to be delivered to—

subparagraph.content: if subparagraph (i) does not apply and a place of delivery has been agreed between the seafarer’s next of kin and the shipowner—that place; or
in any other case—the seafarer’s next of kin; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: bear the costs of the delivery.

section.name: s47
section.heading: Medicines, medical stores and medical guides, etc.

subsection.content: Sections 4, 6, 7 and 8 of the Merchant Shipping (Seafarers) (Medical Stores) Regulation (Cap. 478 sub. leg. X) must be complied with in relation to a ship.

subsection.leadIn: The shipowner of a ship must ensure that a copy of each of the following publications, as amended from time to time, is carried on board the ship—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the “International Medical Guide for Ships” published by the World Health Organization;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the “Medical First Aid Guide for Use in Accidents Involving Dangerous Goods” published by the International Maritime Organization;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the STCW Convention;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the medical section of the “International Code of Signals” published by the International Maritime Organization.

section.name: s48
section.heading: Regular inspections to be carried out regarding medicines, medical stores, etc.

subsection.leadIn: The master of a ship must ensure that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the following are inspected once every year—

subparagraph.content: the medicines and medical stores required to be kept on board the ship under section 4 of the Merchant Shipping (Seafarers) (Medical Stores) Regulation (Cap. 478 sub. leg. X); and
the publications required to be carried on board the ship under section 47; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for each inspection, a record containing the information specified in subsection (2) is compiled and maintained.

subsection.leadIn: The information is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date of inspection and recording;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the name and rank of the person who carried out the inspection; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the result of the inspection.

section.name: s49
section.heading: Medical information relating to seafarers
section.leadIn: If the shipowner or the master of a ship receives any medical information relating to a seafarer working on board the ship, the shipowner or the master must ensure that the information—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is kept confidential; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: may only—

subparagraph.content: be used to facilitate the treatment of the seafarer; or
be used for other purposes that are permitted by law.

section.name: s50
section.heading: Offences

subsection.content: The shipowner or the master of a ship who authorizes or permits the ship to proceed to sea in contravention of section 44, whether or not the ship so proceeds, commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 2 years.
The shipowner of a ship who contravenes section 45(1) or 46(1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 4.
The shipowner of a ship who contravenes section 47(2) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3.
The master of a ship who contravenes section 48(1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3.
The shipowner or the master of a ship who contravenes section 49 commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3.

section.name: s51
section.heading: Procedures for dealing with complaints

subsection.content: The master of a ship must ensure that the on board complaint procedures adopted for the ship comply with all the requirements specified in subsection (2).

subsection.leadIn: The requirements are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the complaint procedures seek to resolve the complaint at the lowest level of ranking;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: despite paragraph (a), the complaint procedures also allow the complainant to complain directly to the master;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the complainant may be accompanied or represented by another seafarer chosen by the complainant during the complaint process;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: there are safeguards to protect the complainant from any adverse action that may be taken by a person against the complainant for lodging the complaint.

section.name: s52
section.heading: Provision of impartial advice
section.leadIn: The master of a ship must appoint a person on board the ship who may, on a confidential basis—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: provide a complainant with impartial advice on the complaint lodged; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: assist the complainant in dealing with the complaint procedures.

section.name: s53
section.heading: Copies of complaint procedures etc. to be provided to seafarers
section.leadIn: The master of a ship must ensure that each seafarer on board the ship is provided with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a copy of the complaint procedures;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the name of the person appointed under section 52; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: the contact information of—

subparagraph.content: the Superintendent; or
for a seafarer who does not reside in Hong Kong, the competent authority of the seafarer’s country of residence.

section.name: s54
section.heading: Offences

subsection.content: The master of a ship who contravenes section 51(1) or 52 commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3.
The master of a ship who contravenes section 53 commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 2.

section.name: s55
section.heading: Wages to be paid in full and at regular intervals
section.leadIn: The employer of a seafarer working on board a ship must pay, in accordance with the employment agreement entered into with the seafarer, the wages and any additional payments due to the seafarer—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in full; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at regular intervals not exceeding 1 month.

section.name: s56
section.heading: Monthly account to be provided to seafarers
section.leadIn: The employer of a seafarer working on board a ship must provide the seafarer with a written account each month setting out—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the amount of wages and any additional payments payable and paid to the seafarer during the month;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: details of all deductions from the amount payable; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if the seafarer is paid in a currency or at a rate of exchange other than that agreed to in the employment agreement concerned, the currency or rate of exchange for the payment.

section.name: s57
section.heading: Allotment of seafarers’ wages

subsection.content: The employer of a seafarer working on board a ship must, subject to the Merchant Shipping (Seafarers) (Allotments) Regulation (Cap. 478 sub. leg. A), ensure that the seafarer may allot all or a part of the seafarer’s wages to a person nominated by the seafarer.

subsection.leadIn: The employer of a seafarer working on board a ship must ensure that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the charge for the allotment, if any, is reasonable in amount; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if applicable, the rate of exchange for the allotment is—

subparagraph.content: the rate agreed between the employer and the seafarer; or
the prevailing market rate.

section.name: s58
section.heading: Offences

subsection.content: The employer of a seafarer who contravenes section 55 commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 2 years.
The employer of a seafarer who contravenes section 56 commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 1.
The employer of a seafarer who contravenes section 57(1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 2.
The employer of a seafarer who contravenes section 57(2) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 6.
It is a defence for a person charged under subsection (2) or (3) to show that the person had taken all reasonable steps to prevent the commission of the offence.

section.name: s59
section.heading: Financial security to provide assistance to seafarers when abandoned

subsection.content: A financial security must be in force in respect of a ship to ensure that any seafarer employed to work on board the ship is provided with assistance when the seafarer is abandoned.

subsection.leadIn: The financial security—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must be in the form of an insurance policy;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must comply with the requirements set out in paragraphs 4, 8, 9, 10 and 12 of Standard A2.5.2 of the ML Convention;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: must not be terminated before the expiry date of the security, unless the provider of the security has given to the Authority at least 30 days prior notice in writing; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: must not prejudice any right of recourse of the provider of the security against third parties.

subsection.content: A seafarer is regarded to be abandoned under the circumstances listed in paragraph 2 of Standard A2.5.2 of the ML Convention.
If subsection (1) or (2) is contravened, the shipowner and the master of the ship concerned each commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 2 years.

section.name: s60
section.heading: Documentary evidence of financial security to be carried on ship

subsection.leadIn: A ship must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: carry on board, in respect of the financial security referred to in section 59(1), a certificate or other documentary evidence issued by each provider of the security; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: have a copy of the certificate or other documentary evidence displayed in a conspicuous position on board the ship, which is accessible to the seafarers on it.

subsection.leadIn: The certificate or other documentary evidence—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must contain the particulars and information set out in Appendix A2-I to the ML Convention; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be in English or accompanied by an English translation.

subsection.content: If subsection (1) or (2) is contravened, the shipowner and the master of the ship concerned each commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3.

division.name: D17
division.heading: Financial Security Relating to Shipowners’ Liability

section.name: s61
section.heading: Financial security to ensure compensation for liability claims

subsection.leadIn: A financial security must be in force in respect of a ship to ensure the payment of compensation for any liability claim brought in respect of any seafarer employed to work on board the ship under—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the law of Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the seafarer’s employment agreement; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: any agreement voluntarily entered into between one or more shipowners’ organizations and one or more seafarers’ organizations that satisfies the following conditions—

subparagraph.content: the agreement relates to the working and living conditions of seafarers;
the shipowner of the ship is a member of the shipowners’ organization or at least one of the shipowners’ organizations, as the case requires; and
the seafarer is a member of the seafarers’ organization or at least one of the seafarers’ organizations, as the case requires.

subsection.leadIn: The financial security—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must be in the form of an insurance policy;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must comply with the requirements set out in paragraphs 8(a), (b), (c), (d) and (e) and 13 of Standard A4.2.1 of the ML Convention; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: must not be terminated before the expiry date of the security, unless the provider of the security has given to the Authority at least 30 days prior notice in writing.

subsection.content: If a financial security referred to in subsection (1) is to be cancelled or terminated, the provider of the security must give the seafarers employed to work on board the ship at least 30 days prior notice in writing.

If a financial security referred to in subsection (1) is cancelled or terminated, the provider of the security must, by written notice within 30 days of the cancellation or termination, inform the Authority of the cancellation or termination.
If subsection (1), (2), (3) or (4) is contravened, the shipowner and the master of the ship concerned each commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: liability claim (責任索償) means a claim in respect of the death or long-term disability of a seafarer due to an occupational injury, illness or hazard.

section.name: s62
section.heading: Documentary evidence of financial security to be carried on ship

subsection.leadIn: A ship must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: carry on board, in respect of the financial security referred to in section 61(1), a certificate or other documentary evidence issued by each provider of the security; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: have a copy of the certificate or other documentary evidence displayed in a conspicuous position on board the ship, which is accessible to the seafarers on it.

subsection.leadIn: The certificate or other documentary evidence—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must contain the particulars and information set out in Appendix A4-I to the ML Convention; and (L.N. 174 of 2018)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be in English or accompanied by an English translation.

subsection.content: If subsection (1) or (2) is contravened, the shipowner and the master of the ship concerned each commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3.

part.name: P3
part.heading: Certification Requirements for Regulated Ships of 500 Gross Tonnage or above

section.name: s63
section.heading: Application
section.leadIn: This Part applies to a regulated ship—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that is a Hong Kong ship; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that is of 500 gross tonnage or above,

division.name: D2
division.heading: Certificates etc. to be Carried on Ships

section.name: s64
section.heading: Ships must not proceed to sea without maritime labour certificate etc.

subsection.leadIn: A ship must not proceed to sea unless there is in force in respect of it—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a maritime labour certificate; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an interim maritime labour certificate.

subsection.leadIn: The ship must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: carry on board the certificate; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: have a copy of the certificate displayed in a conspicuous position on board the ship, which is accessible to the seafarers on it.

subsection.content: The maritime labour certificate of a ship must have the ship’s declaration of maritime labour compliance attached to it.

section.name: s65
section.heading: Copies of maritime labour certificates etc. to be made available on request

subsection.content: If the shipowner or the master of a ship receives a request from any of the persons specified in subsection (2) for a copy of the maritime labour certificate or interim maritime labour certificate of the ship, the shipowner or the master must provide the copy as requested.

subsection.leadIn: The persons are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a seafarer on board the ship or the seafarer’s representative;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Authority or a Government surveyor;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an authorized officer in a port of a ML Convention country;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the shipowner’s representative.

section.name: s66
section.heading: Copy of ML Convention to be displayed on ship
section.content: A ship must have a copy of the ML Convention displayed in a conspicuous position on board the ship, which is accessible to the seafarers on it.

section.name: s67
section.heading: Offences

subsection.content: If section 64(1) is contravened, the shipowner and the master of the ship concerned each commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 2 years.
If section 64(2) or (3) is contravened, the shipowner and the master of the ship concerned each commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3.
The shipowner or the master of a ship who contravenes section 65 commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3.
If section 66 is contravened, the shipowner and the master of the ship concerned each commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 1.

section.name: s68
section.heading: Application for maritime labour certificate

subsection.content: The shipowner of a ship may, by written application, request the Authority to issue a maritime labour certificate in respect of the ship.
The shipowner must provide to the Authority the documents and information specified by the Authority.

section.name: s69
section.heading: Authority may issue maritime labour certificates

subsection.leadIn: Subject to section 70, the Authority may issue a maritime labour certificate in respect of a ship if the Authority is satisfied—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that an inspection of the ship has been carried out by a Government surveyor; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: based on the result of the inspection, that all the Part 2 requirements applicable to the ship are complied with.

subsection.content: Subject to section 75, a maritime labour certificate issued under subsection (1) is valid for the period specified on the certificate, which must not exceed 5 years.

section.name: s70
section.heading: Recognition of inspection carried out before commencement date

subsection.content: If all the conditions specified in subsection (2) are satisfied in relation to a ship, the Authority may issue a maritime labour certificate in respect of the ship even though no inspection of the ship referred to in section 69(1) has been carried out.

subsection.leadIn: The conditions are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: an authorized organization had, before the commencement date—

subparagraph.content: carried out an inspection of the ship; and

based on the result of the inspection, issued a preliminary certificate certifying that the requirements under the ML Convention for each of the items specified in Appendix A5-I to the Convention are complied with in relation to the ship;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if the preliminary certificate was issued more than 3 years before the date of application for the maritime labour certificate, the preliminary certificate bears an endorsement by an authorized organization, indicating that the organization—

subparagraph.content: has inspected the ship between the second anniversary date and third anniversary date of the preliminary certificate; and
is satisfied, based on the result of the inspection, that the requirements under the ML Convention for each of the items specified in the Appendix are complied with in relation to the ship;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the Authority is satisfied, based on the preliminary certificate and any other documents and information provided by the shipowner of the ship, that all the Part 2 requirements applicable to the ship are complied with.

subsection.content: Subject to section 75, a maritime labour certificate issued under subsection (1) is valid for the period specified on the certificate, which must not exceed 5 years from the date of the preliminary certificate.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: authorized organization (獲授權機構) means a member of the International Association of Classification Societies authorized by the Authority to issue preliminary certificates in respect of Hong Kong ships before the commencement date.

section.name: s71
section.heading: Application for renewal of maritime labour certificate

subsection.content: The shipowner of a ship issued with a maritime labour certificate may, by written application before the certificate expires, request the Authority to issue a new maritime labour certificate in respect of the ship.
The shipowner must provide to the Authority the documents and information specified by the Authority.

section.name: s72
section.heading: Renewal of maritime labour certificate

subsection.leadIn: The Authority may issue a new maritime labour certificate in respect of a ship if the Authority is satisfied—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that an inspection of the ship has been carried out by a Government surveyor; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: based on the result of the inspection, that all the Part 2 requirements applicable to the ship are complied with.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to section 75, a maritime labour certificate issued under subsection (1) is valid for the period specified on the certificate, which must not exceed 5 years from—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the inspection is completed within 3 months before the date of expiry of the current maritime labour certificate, the date of expiry of the current certificate;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the inspection is completed more than 3 months before the date of expiry of the current maritime labour certificate, the date of completion of the inspection.

section.name: s73
section.heading: Intermediate inspection

subsection.leadIn: The shipowner of a ship issued with a maritime labour certificate must ensure that an intermediate inspection of the ship is carried out—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the certificate is issued under section 69 or 72, between the second anniversary date and third anniversary date of the certificate;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the certificate is issued under section 70, during the period for carrying out an intermediate inspection specified on the certificate.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) does not apply if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the maritime labour certificate is issued under section 70; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the preliminary certificate issued in respect of the ship bears an endorsement as described in section 70(2)(b).

section.name: s74
section.heading: Endorsement for intermediate inspection

subsection.content: The shipowner of a ship issued with a maritime labour certificate may, by written application, request the Authority to make an endorsement for intermediate inspection on the certificate.

subsection.leadIn: The Authority may make such an endorsement if the Authority is satisfied—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that an intermediate inspection of the ship has been carried out by a Government surveyor; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: based on the result of the inspection, that all the Part 2 requirements applicable to the ship are complied with.

subdivision.name: SD4
subdivision.heading: Circumstances under which Maritime Labour Certificate Ceases to be Valid

section.name: s75
section.heading: Circumstances under which maritime labour certificate ceases to be valid

subsection.content: The maritime labour certificate of a ship ceases to be valid under any of the circumstances specified in subsection (2).

subsection.leadIn: The circumstances are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the ship ceases to be registered in Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person identified on the certificate as the shipowner of the ship ceases to assume responsibility for the operation of the ship;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a substantial change has been made to the structure or equipment of the accommodation for seafarers, the recreational and communications facilities for seafarers, or the food and catering facilities of the ship;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: the certificate does not bear an endorsement for intermediate inspection—

subparagraph.content: if the certificate is issued under section 69 or 72, on the third anniversary date of the certificate;
if the certificate is issued under section 70, on the date immediately after the period for carrying out an intermediate inspection specified on the certificate.

section.name: s76
section.heading: Circumstances under which shipowners may apply for interim maritime labour certificate
section.leadIn: The shipowner of a ship may request an interim maritime labour certificate to be issued in respect of the ship if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the ship is a new ship on delivery;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the ship has changed its flag and has just been registered in Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the shipowner assumes responsibility for the operation of the ship for the first time.

section.name: s77
section.heading: Application for interim maritime labour certificate

subsection.content: The shipowner of a ship may, by written application, request the Authority to issue an interim maritime labour certificate in respect of the ship.
The shipowner must provide to the Authority the documents and information specified by the Authority.

section.name: s78
section.heading: Authority may issue interim maritime labour certificates
section.leadIn: The Authority may issue an interim maritime labour certificate in respect of a ship if the Authority is satisfied—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that an inspection of the ship has been carried out by a Government surveyor; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: based on the result of the inspection, that—

subparagraph.content: the ship has adequate measures in place to comply with all the Part 2 requirements applicable to the ship;
the master of the ship is familiar with those requirements and the responsibilities for complying with those requirements; and
the shipowner of the ship has submitted an application for a declaration of maritime labour compliance in respect of the ship.

section.name: s79
section.heading: Period of validity of interim maritime labour certificate

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2), an interim maritime labour certificate is valid for the period specified on the certificate, which must not exceed 6 months.

subsection.leadIn: The interim maritime labour certificate of a ship ceases to be valid if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the ship ceases to be registered in Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person identified on the certificate as the shipowner of the ship ceases to assume responsibility for the operation of the ship; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a substantial change has been made to the structure or equipment of the accommodation for seafarers, the recreational and communications facilities for seafarers, or the food and catering facilities of the ship.

section.name: s80
section.heading: Interim maritime labour certificate not renewable
section.content: An interim maritime labour certificate is not renewable.

section.name: s81
section.heading: Application for declaration of maritime labour compliance

subsection.content: The shipowner of a ship may, by written application, request the Authority to issue a declaration of maritime labour compliance in respect of the ship.

subsection.leadIn: The shipowner must provide to the Authority—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the documents and information specified by the Authority; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a proposal on the measures that the shipowner will adopt to ensure that all the Part 2 requirements applicable to the ship are complied with.

section.name: s82
section.heading: Authority may issue declaration of maritime labour compliance

subsection.content: The Authority may, on application, issue Part I of a declaration of maritime labour compliance in respect of a ship.

subsection.leadIn: Part I of the declaration of maritime labour compliance must contain—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the registration details of the ship; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any exemption from complying with any Part 2 requirement granted under section 114.

subsection.content: The Authority may issue Part II of the declaration of maritime labour compliance if the Authority is satisfied that the proposed measures referred to in section 81(2)(b) are sufficient to ensure that all the Part 2 requirements applicable to the ship are complied with.

subsection.leadIn: Part II of the declaration of maritime labour compliance must contain—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the proposed measures; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an endorsement by the Authority that the proposed measures are sufficient to ensure that all the Part 2 requirements applicable to the ship are complied with.

section.name: s83
section.heading: Results and reports of relevant inspections to be appended to declaration of maritime labour compliance

subsection.content: The shipowner of a ship must ensure that the results and reports of all relevant inspections carried out in respect of the ship are inscribed in or appended to the declaration of maritime labour compliance issued in respect of the ship.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: relevant inspection (有關檢查) means—(a)an inspection carried out for issuing a maritime labour certificate;(b)an intermediate inspection; or(c)an inspection carried out under Part 5.

part.name: P4
part.heading: Compliance Reports for Regulated Ships of Less than 500 Gross Tonnage

section.name: s84
section.heading: Application
section.leadIn: This Part applies to a regulated ship—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that is a Hong Kong ship; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that is of less than 500 gross tonnage,

division.name: D2
division.heading: Compliance Reports etc. to be Carried on Ships

section.name: s85
section.heading: Ships must not proceed to sea without compliance reports

subsection.leadIn: Subject to section 87, a ship must not proceed to sea unless it carries on board a compliance report that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: certifies that all the Part 2 requirements applicable to the ship are complied with; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: was issued not more than 3 years ago.

subsection.content: A copy of the report must be displayed in a conspicuous position on board the ship, which is accessible to the seafarers on it.
The report must have the ship’s declaration of maritime labour compliance attached to it.

section.name: s86
section.heading: Copies of compliance reports to be made available on request

subsection.content: If the shipowner or the master of a ship receives a request from any of the persons specified in subsection (2) for a copy of the compliance report carried on board the ship under section 85, the shipowner or the master must provide the copy as requested.

subsection.leadIn: The persons are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a seafarer on board the ship or the seafarer’s representative;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Authority or a Government surveyor;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an authorized officer in a port of a ML Convention country;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the shipowner’s representative.

section.name: s87
section.heading: Exception to section 85
section.content: Section 85 does not prevent a ship from proceeding to sea if there is in force in respect of it a maritime labour certificate or an interim maritime labour certificate pursuant to section 95.

section.name: s88
section.heading: Copy of ML Convention to be displayed on ship
section.content: A ship must have a copy of the ML Convention displayed in a conspicuous position on board the ship, which is accessible to the seafarers on it.

section.name: s89
section.heading: Offences

subsection.content: If section 85(1) is contravened, the shipowner and the master of the ship concerned each commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 2 years.
If section 85(2) or (3) is contravened, the shipowner and the master of the ship concerned each commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3.
The shipowner or the master of a ship who contravenes section 86 commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3.
If section 88 is contravened, the shipowner and the master of the ship concerned each commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 1.

section.name: s90
section.heading: Application for compliance reports

subsection.content: The shipowner of a ship may, by written application, request the Authority to issue a compliance report in respect of the ship.
The shipowner must provide to the Authority the documents and information specified by the Authority.

section.name: s91
section.heading: Authority may issue compliance reports

subsection.leadIn: The Authority may issue a compliance report in respect of a ship if the Authority is satisfied—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that an inspection of the ship has been carried out by a Government surveyor; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: based on the result of the inspection, that all the Part 2 requirements applicable to the ship are complied with.

subsection.content: A compliance report must specify the date of inspection.

section.name: s92
section.heading: Application for declaration of maritime labour compliance

subsection.content: The shipowner of a ship may, by written application, request the Authority to issue a declaration of maritime labour compliance in respect of the ship.

subsection.leadIn: The shipowner must provide to the Authority—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the documents and information specified by the Authority; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a proposal on the measures that the shipowner will adopt to ensure that all the Part 2 requirements applicable to the ship are complied with.

section.name: s93
section.heading: Authority may issue declaration of maritime labour compliance

subsection.content: The Authority may, on application, issue Part I of a declaration of maritime labour compliance in respect of a ship.

subsection.leadIn: Part I of the declaration of maritime labour compliance must contain—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the registration details of the ship; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any exemption from complying with any Part 2 requirement granted under section 114.

subsection.content: The Authority may issue Part II of the declaration of maritime labour compliance if the Authority is satisfied that the proposed measures referred to in section 92(2)(b) are sufficient to ensure that all the Part 2 requirements applicable to the ship are complied with.

subsection.leadIn: Part II of the declaration of maritime labour compliance must contain—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the proposed measures; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an endorsement by the Authority that the proposed measures are sufficient to ensure that all the Part 2 requirements applicable to the ship are complied with.

section.name: s94
section.heading: Results and reports of relevant inspections to be appended to declaration of maritime labour compliance

subsection.content: The shipowner of a ship must ensure that the results and reports of all relevant inspections carried out in respect of the ship are inscribed in or appended to the declaration of maritime labour compliance issued in respect of the ship.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: relevant inspection (有關檢查) means—(a)an inspection carried out for issuing a compliance report; or(b)an inspection carried out under Part 5.

section.name: s95
section.heading: Shipowner may apply for maritime labour certificate etc.
