subsection.content: The shipowner of a ship may apply for a maritime labour certificate or an interim maritime labour certificate to be issued in respect of the ship, as if the ship were one that falls within section 63.

If a maritime labour certificate or an interim maritime labour certificate is issued and is in force in respect of a ship, Part 3 applies to the ship, as if the ship were one that falls within section 63.

section.name: s96
section.heading: Application
section.content: This Division applies to a regulated ship that is a Hong Kong ship, wherever it may be.

section.name: s97
section.heading: Authority may ascertain compliance with requirements under Parts 2, 3 and 4
section.content: The Authority may, at all reasonable times, board and inspect a ship for ascertaining whether the requirements under Part 2, 3 or 4 are complied with.

section.name: s98
section.heading: Investigations into non-compliance

subsection.content: On receiving a complaint or obtaining evidence on any of the matters specified in subsection (2) in relation to a ship, the Authority may board and inspect the ship for investigating into the matter.

subsection.leadIn: The matters are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: there is a deficiency in complying with any requirement under Part 2, 3 or 4;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: there is a serious deficiency in implementing the compliance measures.

subsection.content: The Authority must keep the source of the complaint or evidence confidential.

section.name: s99
section.heading: Powers of Authority in inspections
section.leadIn: For the purposes of sections 97 and 98, the Authority may board and inspect a ship and—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: carry out an examination or a test in respect of any part of, or any equipment or thing on, the ship;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: require the shipowner or the master of the ship, or a seafarer on board the ship, to produce the documents and provide the information specified by the Authority;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: examine and copy any document referred to in paragraph (b);

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: take measurements and photographs, and make records, as the Authority considers necessary; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: take or remove, for the purpose of analysis, samples of products, cargoes, provisions, drinking water, materials and substances on board the ship.

section.name: s100
section.heading: Authority may require rectification of deficiencies

subsection.leadIn: This section applies if the Authority identifies, from an inspection of a ship—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any deficiency in complying with any requirement under Part 2, 3 or 4; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any deficiency in implementing the compliance measures.

subsection.content: The Authority may, by written notice to the shipowner and the master of the ship, require the deficiency to be rectified within the time specified in the notice.

subsection.leadIn: If the Authority is satisfied that the deficiency falls within subsection (4), the Authority may also—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by written notice to the shipowner and the master of the ship, direct that the ship must not proceed to sea until the deficiency has been rectified; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: take steps to prohibit the ship from proceeding to sea in contravention of the direction.

subsection.leadIn: The deficiency is one that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: constitutes a serious or repeated breach of any requirement under Part 2, 3 or 4; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: represents a significant danger to the safety, health or security of the seafarers on board the ship.

subsection.content: If the shipowner of a ship is aggrieved by a decision of the Authority under subsection (2) or (3), the shipowner may, within 5 working days after receiving notice of the decision, appeal to the Administrative Appeals Board against the decision.
The appeal does not affect the operation of the decision unless the Authority directs otherwise in writing.

section.name: s101
section.heading: Authority may withdraw maritime labour certificate etc. if deficiency not rectified

subsection.leadIn: This section applies if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Authority has issued a written notice in respect of a ship under section 100(2); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a deficiency specified in the notice is not rectified in accordance with the notice.

subsection.content: The Authority may, by written notice to the shipowner and the master of the ship, withdraw the maritime labour certificate, interim maritime labour certificate or compliance report issued in respect of the ship.
When deciding whether to withdraw the certificate or report issued in respect of the ship, the Authority must take into account the seriousness and frequency of occurrence of the deficiency.
On receiving a notice under subsection (2), the shipowner and the master of the ship must deliver the certificate or report to the Authority immediately.
The shipowner or the master of the ship may, after the deficiency has been rectified, apply to the Authority for the return of the certificate or report.
If the Authority is satisfied that the deficiency has been rectified, the Authority must, by written notice to the applicant, return the certificate or report to the applicant.
If subsection (4) is contravened, the shipowner and the master of the ship concerned each commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 6.

section.name: s102
section.heading: Preparation of reports

subsection.content: The Authority must prepare a report on an inspection carried out under section 97 or 98.

subsection.leadIn: The report—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: must set out—

subparagraph.content: the date of commencement and completion of the inspection; and
the details of any deficiency identified and the date when the deficiency is rectified; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be in the Chinese or English language.

subsection.content: The Authority must furnish a copy of the report to the shipowner and the master of the ship concerned.

subsection.leadIn: A copy of the report must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be displayed in a conspicuous position on board the ship, which is accessible to the seafarers on it; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on request by a seafarer’s representative, be provided to the representative.

subsection.content: If subsection (4) is contravened, the shipowner and the master of the ship concerned each commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3.

section.name: s103
section.heading: Application
section.leadIn: This Division applies to a regulated ship—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that is a non-Hong Kong ship; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that is within the waters of Hong Kong in the normal course of business or for operational reasons.

section.name: s104
section.heading: Authority may ascertain compliance with requirements under ML Convention

subsection.content: The Authority may, at all reasonable times, board and inspect a ship for ascertaining whether the requirements under the ML Convention are complied with.

Without limiting subsection (1), if the ship flies the flag of a ML Convention country, the Authority may examine any document certifying the ship’s compliance with the requirements under the Convention, which are issued in accordance with the law of the country.

section.name: s105
section.heading: Investigations into non-compliance

subsection.content: On receiving a complaint or obtaining evidence that there is a deficiency in complying with any requirement under the ML Convention in relation to a ship, the Authority may board and inspect the ship for investigating into the non-compliance.
The Authority must keep the source of the complaint or evidence confidential.

section.name: s106
section.heading: Powers of Authority in inspections
section.content: For the purposes of sections 104 and 105, the Authority may exercise any of the powers under section 99 in relation to a non-Hong Kong ship as if the ship were a Hong Kong ship.

section.name: s107
section.heading: Authority may require rectification of deficiencies

subsection.content: This section applies if the Authority identifies, from an inspection of a ship, any deficiency in complying with any requirement under the ML Convention.
The Authority may, by written notice to the master of the ship, require the deficiency to be rectified within the time specified in the notice.

subsection.leadIn: If the Authority is satisfied that the deficiency falls within subsection (4), the Authority may also—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: by written notice to the master of the ship, direct that the ship must not proceed to sea until—

subparagraph.content: the deficiency has been rectified; or

the submission by the master of the ship of a plan for rectifying the deficiency and of evidence that the plan will be implemented in an expeditious manner, both of which must be satisfactory to the Authority; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: take steps to prohibit the ship from proceeding to sea in contravention of the direction.

subsection.leadIn: The deficiency is one that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: constitutes a serious or repeated breach of any requirement under the ML Convention; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: represents a significant danger to the safety, health or security of the seafarers on board the ship.

section.name: s108
section.heading: Authority may authorize Government surveyors
section.content: The Authority may authorize a Government surveyor to perform the Authority’s functions under this Part.

section.name: s109
section.heading: Offence for obstructing Authority or Government surveyor
section.content: A person who obstructs the Authority or a Government surveyor in carrying out the functions under this Part commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 2 years.

section.name: s110
section.heading: Authority may appoint Government surveyors
section.content: The Authority may appoint a person to be a Government surveyor for the purposes of this Regulation.

section.name: s111
section.heading: Authority may recognize organizations

subsection.content: The Authority may recognize an organization for carrying out any of the acts specified in subsection (2) in relation to a ship.

subsection.leadIn: The acts are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: to carry out an inspection of the ship and—

subparagraph.content: to issue or renew a maritime labour certificate in respect of the ship;
to make an endorsement for intermediate inspection on the maritime labour certificate of the ship;
to issue an interim maritime labour certificate in respect of the ship; or
to issue a compliance report in respect of the ship;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to consider the measures proposed by the shipowner of the ship to ensure compliance with all the Part 2 requirements applicable to the ship, and to issue Part II of the declaration of maritime labour compliance in respect of the ship;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to require the rectification of any deficiency in complying with any Part 2 requirement applicable to a ship identified from an inspection of the ship.

division.name: D2
division.heading: Miscellaneous Powers and Duties of Authority

section.name: s112
section.heading: Authority may cancel Convention-related documents

subsection.content: If the Authority has reasonable ground to believe that a Convention-related document issued in respect of a ship was issued on the basis of false or erroneous information, the Authority may cancel the document by written notice to the shipowner of the ship.
The Authority must give reasons for cancelling a Convention-related document.
On receiving a notice under subsection (1), the shipowner of the ship must deliver the Convention-related document to the Authority immediately.
The shipowner of a ship who contravenes subsection (3) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 6.

section.name: s113
section.heading: Forms of Convention-related documents
section.content: The Authority may specify the form of a Convention-related document.

section.name: s114
section.heading: Authority may grant exemptions

subsection.content: Subject to sections 29 and 30, the Authority may exempt a Hong Kong ship or a class or description of Hong Kong ships from complying with any Part 2 requirement, subject to the conditions the Authority thinks fit.
The Authority may alter or cancel an exemption granted under subsection (1).

section.name: s115
section.heading: Authority may request ML Convention countries to inspect Hong Kong ships

subsection.content: The Authority may, while a Hong Kong ship is within the waters of a ML Convention country, request the competent authority of the country to carry out any of the acts specified in subsection (2) in relation to the ship on the Authority’s behalf.

subsection.leadIn: The acts are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: to carry out an inspection of the ship and—

subparagraph.content: to issue or renew a maritime labour certificate in respect of the ship;
to make an endorsement for intermediate inspection on the maritime labour certificate of the ship;
to issue an interim maritime labour certificate in respect of the ship; or
to issue a compliance report in respect of the ship;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to consider the measures proposed by the shipowner of the ship to ensure compliance with all the Part 2 requirements applicable to the ship, and to issue Part II of the declaration of maritime labour compliance in respect of the ship.

section.name: s116
section.heading: Authority may on request of ML Convention countries carry out certain acts in relation to ships flying their flags

subsection.content: If a ship that flies the flag of a ML Convention country is within the waters of Hong Kong, the Authority may, on a written request of the competent authority of the country, carry out any of the acts specified in subsection (2) in relation to the ship on behalf of the authority.

subsection.leadIn: The acts are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to review the measures proposed by the shipowner of the ship to ensure compliance with the requirements under the ML Convention;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to carry out an inspection of the ship;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: based on the result of the review or inspection, to make an endorsement or issue a certificate regarding the working and living conditions of seafarers on board the ship.

section.name: s1
section.leadIn: A seafarer’s employment agreement must contain the following information and terms—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the full name, date of birth or age, and birthplace of the seafarer;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the name and address of the employer;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the place and date of entering into the agreement;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the capacity in which the seafarer is employed;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the seafarer’s wages or the formula for calculating the wages;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.leadIn: the term of the agreement and—

subparagraph.content: if the agreement is for an indefinite period, the period of notice to be given by the employer and the seafarer for terminating the agreement;
if the agreement is for a definite period, the date on which it expires; and
if the agreement is to cover a specific voyage, the port of destination and the time that has to lapse after the ship’s arrival at the port before the seafarer is to be discharged;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the grounds for early termination of the agreement and the period of notice to be given by the employer and the seafarer for early termination of the agreement;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: the health and social security protection benefits to be provided to the seafarer by the employer, if any;
the seafarer’s entitlement to repatriation;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: the seafarer’s entitlement to paid leave and, where the leave is not taken, the amount of payment in lieu or the formula for calculating the amount; and

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: the seafarer’s entitlement to shore leave, the duration of which is to be determined by reference to the operational requirements of the seafarer’s capacity.

section.name: s2
section.content: The employment agreement must not contain any provision that seeks to forgo the seafarer’s entitlement to paid leave.

section.name: s3
section.leadIn: The employment agreement must contain provisions regarding the employer’s liability for the seafarer’s sickness or injury and related matters to the effect that— (L.N. 21 of 2024)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the employer must bear the costs in respect of any sickness or injury of the seafarer—

subparagraph.content: occurring between the date of commencement of employment and the date on which the seafarer is repatriated; or
arising from the employment between those dates;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.leadIn: the employer must defray the expenses for the seafarer’s medical care (including medical treatment and the supply of the necessary medicines and therapeutic appliances) and the seafarer’s boarding and lodging away from home until whichever is the earliest of the following—

subparagraph.content: the seafarer has recovered;
the sickness or incapacity suffered by the seafarer has been declared to be of a permanent character;
the expiry of 16 weeks from the commencement of sickness or the date of injury;

paragraph.name: d
e
paragraph.leadIn: if the sickness or injury results in incapacity for work, and the seafarer is repatriated, the employer is liable to pay 80% of the wages to the seafarer for the period beginning on the date after the repatriation until whichever is the earlier of the following—

subparagraph.content: the date when the seafarer has recovered;
the expiry of 16 weeks from the commencement of sickness or the date of injury;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.leadIn: if the seafarer dies on board the ship or ashore in the course of employment, the employer must— (L.N. 21 of 2024)

subparagraph.content: make arrangements for delivering the body or ashes of the seafarer in accordance with section 46A of the Merchant Shipping (Seafarers) (Working and Living Conditions) Regulation (Cap. 478 sub. leg. AF); and

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: if the seafarer leaves any property on board the ship following the seafarer’s sickness, injury or death, the employer must take measures for safeguarding the property, and for returning the property to the seafarer or to the seafarer’s next of kin.

section.name: s4
section.leadIn: The employment agreement must contain a reference to any agreement voluntarily entered into between one or more shipowners’ organizations and one or more seafarers’ organizations (relevant agreement) that satisfies the following conditions—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the relevant agreement relates to the working and living conditions of seafarers;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the shipowner of the ship on which the seafarer is employed to work is a member of the shipowners’ organization or at least one of the shipowners’ organizations, as the case requires; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the seafarer is a member of the seafarers’ organization or at least one of the seafarers’ organizations, as the case requires.

section.name: s5
section.content: For the purposes of section 1(f)(i) of this Schedule, the period of notice to be given by the employer for terminating the employment agreement must not be shorter than that to be given by the seafarer.

section.name: s6
section.leadIn: For the purposes of section 1(g) of this Schedule—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the employer and the seafarer must give at least 7 days prior notice for early termination of the employment agreement; but

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the seafarer may give less than 7 days prior notice for early termination of the agreement—

subparagraph.content: on compassionate grounds; or
on other urgent grounds as specified in the agreement.

section.name: s7
section.content: For the purposes of section 1(j) of this Schedule, the paid leave for the seafarer must not be less than 2.5 days per month of employment.

section.name: s1
section.leadIn: The accommodation for seafarers working on board a ship must comply with the requirements set out in Standard A3.1 and Guideline B3.1 of the ML Convention on the following areas—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: general requirements for accommodation;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: ventilation and heating;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: lighting;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: sleeping rooms;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: mess rooms;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: sanitary and laundry facilities; and

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: prevention of noise and vibration.

section.name: s2
section.leadIn: The ventilation of the accommodation of the ship must comply with the requirements specified in the following provisions of the Accommodation Regulation—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: section 16(7); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the ship falls within the description set out in section 16(2), (3) or (4) of the Regulation, section 16(2), (3) or (4) respectively.

section.name: s3
section.content: If a heating system is required for the ship, the system must comply with the standard of heating as specified in section 14(1) of the Accommodation Regulation.

section.name: s4
section.content: The accommodation of the ship must comply with the requirements on lighting set out in section 15 of the Accommodation Regulation.

section.name: s5
section.content: If any of the employed seafarers is required to sleep on board the ship, sleeping accommodation must be provided on board the ship.

section.name: s6
section.content: If the ship carries 15 or more seafarers and is engaged in a voyage of more than 3 days’ duration, there must be hospital accommodation on board the ship which is to be used exclusively for medical purpose.

section.name: s7
section.content: The hospital accommodation must, in all weathers, be easily accessible, provide comfortable housing for the occupants and be conducive to their receiving prompt and proper attention.

section.name: s8
section.leadIn: The hospital accommodation must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: comply with the relevant requirements set out in Guideline B3.1 of the ML Convention; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: have at least one bed for every 50 seafarers working on board the ship.

part.name: P3
part.heading: Bedding, Mess Utensils and Miscellaneous Provisions

section.name: s9
section.leadIn: The following provisions must be carried on board the ship and be made available to the seafarers working on it—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: clean bedding of good quality;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: plates, cups and other mess utensils which are made of durable material and can be easily cleaned; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: towels, soap and toilet paper.

section.name: s10
section.content: The ship must comply with the relevant requirements set out in the Code on Noise Levels on Board Ships published by the International Maritime Organization, as from time to time revised or amended by any revision or amendment that applies to Hong Kong.

section.name: s11
section.leadIn: The ship must have a space on open deck—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: which seafarers working on board the ship can have access to when off duty; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: which must be of an adequate size, having regard to the size of the ship and the number of seafarers on board the ship.

section.name: s12
section.content: The ship must have separate offices or a common ship’s office for use by the deck department and engine room department.

section.name: s13
section.leadIn: If separate facilities are provided for engine department personnel to change their clothes, the facilities must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be located outside the machinery space but have easy access to it; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be fitted with individual clothes lockers, as well as with tubs or showers, or both, and washbasins having hot and cold running fresh water.

section.name: s14
section.content: If the ship is regularly engaged in voyages to mosquito-infested ports, the ship must be fitted with devices against admission of mosquitoes as set out in section 37 of the Accommodation Regulation.

schedule.name: sch3
schedule.heading: Requirements for Recreational and Communications Facilities

section.name: s1
section.content: Appropriate recreational facilities, spaces, amenities and services, as adapted to meet the special needs of seafarers on board the ship, must be provided on board the ship.

section.name: s2
section.leadIn: The following facilities must be available on board the ship—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a television; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: reading materials consisting of vocational and other books.

section.name: s3
section.content: Seafarers on board the ship must, if practicable, be provided with reasonable access to ship-to-shore telephone communications, and email and Internet facilities.

section.name: s4
section.content: The charges for the use of the communications facilities referred to in section 3 of this Schedule must be reasonable.

section.name: s1
section.content: There must be a qualified cook in the catering department of a ship if the prescribed manning of the ship, as set out in the Minimum Safe Manning Certificate issued in respect of the ship under the Merchant Shipping (Safety) (Minimum Safe Manning Certificate) Regulation (Cap. 369 sub. leg. AS), is not less than 10 persons.

section.name: s2
section.leadIn: For the purposes of section 1 of this Schedule, a seafarer is a qualified cook if the seafarer is at least 18 years of age and—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the seafarer has completed a training course—

subparagraph.content: which covers practical cookery, food and personal hygiene, food storage, stock control, environmental protection and catering health and safety; and
which is recognized by the Authority as providing sufficient training for working as a ship’s cook;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the seafarer—

subparagraph.content: has worked as a ship’s cook on board a seagoing ship, whether a Hong Kong ship or not, for not less than 12 months, or has comparable experience; and
has completed a top-up course recognized by the Authority as providing sufficient supplementary training for working as a ship’s cook; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the seafarer is issued with a certificate of qualification as a ship’s cook by the competent authority of a country that is a party to the Ships’ Cooks Convention, or of a ML Convention country.

section.name: s3
section.leadIn: If a ship is not required to have a qualified cook on board the ship under section 1 of this Schedule, each seafarer processing food in the galley must be trained or instructed in—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: food and personal hygiene; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the handling and storage of food.
